metadata.case_name: Amar Singh v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Appellant appointed as District and Sessions Judge in former Bikaner State on January 29, 1948, in grade Rs. 500-40-700, worked till April 7, 1949.

New State of Rajasthan formed on April 7, 1949, by integration of States including Bikaner via Covenant; Article XVI guarantees continuance in service on not less advantageous conditions than on November 1, 1948, or compensation or pension.
On December 9, 1949, Rajasthan Government transferred appellant as District and Sessions Judge, Churu to Ganganagar.

Rajasthan Gazette Notification dated May 25, 1950, made provisional ad hoc postings of judicial officers; appellant posted as Civil and Additional Sessions Judge in Jaipur Division; stated as without prejudice to creation of Judicial Service.
Increment of Rs. 40 sanctioned on July 31, 1950 (effect from March 23, 1950), raising salary from Rs. 540 to Rs. 580, describing appellant as District and Sessions Judge in Bikaner Division.
Appellant made representation on September 11, 1950, against ad hoc posting of May 25, 1950; understood as without prejudice to permanent claims; allegation admitted by opposite party.
Appellant appointed substantively as Civil Judge on April 23, 1951, placed in Group C (Civil Judges and Munsiffs) at No. 18; pay and emoluments retained as Rs. 500-40-700, increments unaffected.
Appellant filed writ petition on April 3, 1954, claiming entitlement to District and Sessions Judge post under Covenant, reduction in rank without opportunity violating Art. 311.

Rajasthan High Court by judgment dated September 5, 1955, held April 23, 1951 appointment as ad hoc, directed Government to provide machinery per Constitution for recruitment to Rajasthan Judicial Service.
Special leave to appeal granted by Supreme Court on April 16, 1956.
Post High Court order, Rajasthan Government reframed rules, made fresh appointments published in Gazette; appellant selected and appointed as Civil Judge.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appointments post-integration constituted reduction in rank without opportunity to show cause, violating Article 311 of the Constitution.
Effect of Article XVI of the Covenant and whether old service contracts continued or terminated on integration into new State.
Whether appellant entitled to permanent District and Sessions Judge post under integration guarantees.

petitioner_arguments.text: Transfer order of December 9, 1949, as District Judge constituted election by new Government to continue in original post; later ad hoc postings and substantive Civil Judge appointment reduced rank without show cause, violating Art. 311.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article XVI of Covenant; Article 311 Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Entitled to District and Sessions Judge post in integrated setup per guarantee of not less advantageous conditions.
Increment sanction and descriptions as District Judge indicate permanent continuance.

respondent_arguments.text: On integration, old contracts terminate; new service on terms set by new State; previous postings transitional and temporary.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: State of Madras v. K. M. Rajagopalan

respondent_arguments.text: Conditions not less advantageous than on Nov 1, 1948; pay and grading retained.

court_reasoning.text: On State integration, old service contracts automatically terminate; servants serve on new terms imposed by new State, per master-servant principle.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Settled by State of Madras v. K. M. Rajagopalan, following Privy Council and House of Lords.

court_reasoning.text: Article XVI provides options (continuance, compensation, pension), indicating termination of old contracts and fresh terms not less advantageous than Nov 1, 1948; guarantee fulfilled as pay/emoluments same.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No guarantee of same or better conditions, only not less advantageous.

court_reasoning.text: December 9, 1949 transfer and increment orders were transitional pending reorganisation; ad hoc postings explicit as provisional.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No permanent posting spelled from descriptive references.

court_reasoning.text: April 23, 1951 appointment (or later post-High Court) is first substantive in new State; no prior permanent post, hence no reduction in rank; Art. 311 not attracted.

holdings.text: Old contracts terminate on integration; new service on fresh terms by new State.
No reduction in rank as prior postings temporary; Article 311 not violated.
Article XVI guarantee fulfilled; no entitlement to specific District Judge post.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. K. M. Rajagopalan
precedents_cited.relevance: Old contracts terminate on State absorption/integration; new terms by new State.
Supports principle on change of sovereignty and service contracts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nokes v. Doncaster Amalgamated Collieries Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports principle on change of masters in employment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Virendra Singh v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between property rights and contractual rights on change of sovereignty.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ for mandamus under 226; claim of reduction in rank under 311.

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Covenant
statutes_cited.relevance: Guarantee on integration for service conditions.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected appellant's contentions, holding no reduction in rank or Art. 311 violation as prior postings were temporary and old contracts terminated on integration; Art. XVI guarantee fulfilled.

key_quotes.text: when one State is absorbed in another... all contracts of service between the prior Government and its servants automatically terminate and thereafter those who elect to serve in the new State... serve on such terms and conditions as the new State may choose to impose.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on effect of State integration on service contracts.

key_quotes.text: There was no guarantee that they would be the same or better.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets Art. XVI as only 'not less advantageous', not identical posts.

key_quotes.text: no question of reduction in rank can arise and so Art. 311 is not attracted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
